pros: I feel good that I am making a difference in so many lives.  As long as you are focused on the patient and do what you are supposed to be doing, it's a great place to work.  Love the management and my coworkers who are truly committed to our mission and vision.
cons: Working with negative people, who no matter what the company does for them, they feel entitled to have more and do whatever they want, they break the rules and don't get caught but everyone else sees them.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Indianapolis, IN
cons: felt there was no room for growth or advancement of my career

review_title: A lot of Chiefs not enough Indians
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Awesome coworkers that you get to call family/friends depending on which location you work

cons: I did not have a very enjoyable experience. Not one to bad mouth a company.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The providers there were great to work with .
cons: The nine months I was there we went through a new manager he moved on our clinical manager left we had no MAs they had all quit . When they did finally hire people they did it all at once hired who they could and was very unappreciative of the staff they did have who had been there and worked hard through the tough times . The culture there when I quit was awful no team work and too much drama .

pros: Horrible place to work do not even pass go stay away. Culture is very toxic and racist leadership don’t even want to connect with their own patients. Stop pitching that your benefits are great because if people looked at other companies they would know that your benefits aren’t the best
cons: Horrible pay, toxic leadership, toxic culture, no accountability, providers are racist towards patients and other employees, executive leadership doesn’t listen and doesn’t care about the poor working environment they only care about money which when insurance companies find out how they don’t care for patients they only refer them out hopefully they move patients to other providers

pros: Great benefits and smaller organization makes it easier to create connections
cons: Staffing has been a problem, many disconnects between managers and employees has caused a lot of friction

review_title: Good Job, But Not Without Its Faults
pros: The health insurance benefits are the best I've ever had. I think my pay is fair. I like most of my co-workers.
cons: I wish there was more transparency from leadership about decisions that are made. There are definitely a lot of "politics" in this company. It is very telling that the employee demographic is vastly female while leadership is mostly male. More time off would be nice too.

job_title: Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Autonomy is primary situation for employees.
cons: Constantly changing leadership makes progress difficult.

pros: Working alone in office due to covid
cons: Not much training due to covid

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Excellent healthcare coverage. They have a keurig,  but they don't like ordering k cups  because they're too expensive and they don't pay for creamer or sugar.  There's no silverware provided or actual paper towels in their kitchen.  Plan on bringing a portable kitchen with you.
cons: My coworker was like the paparazzi and documented my behaviors throughout the day and told my manager  how many times I got up to get coffee and I got in trouble.  I wish I could find someone who loved me as much as she was obsessed with me.  Very odd management and coworker relationships, gossip is highly encouraged within the team.  I felt like I was living a real life version of mean girls  except everyone was older and would throw a temper tantrum if you were late one minute from lunch.  Understandable, but there are more important things to stress over, like maybe helping patients and arguing with insurance companies to get authorizations approved, but hey some people like to focus on their coworkers and literally document their every moves.  To each their own .  Also, the traditional 90 day new hire policy of learning and making mistakes does not apply here, you can be written up within the first two weeks for not knowing the rules by heart.  And by rules, I mean the ones that the manager feels like she wants to enforce that day, because they don't   Apply to all coworkers, just certain individuals who she is not fond of.  Whatever regina George.

pros: I got a broad range of experiences at the Jane Pauley Community Health Center. They opened door for me that I never thought existed.
cons: I had to travel quite a bit for my internship. I worked at the clinic in Anderson and lived in Indianapolis. My internship was unpaid, but that is normal for the degree that I was seeking.

pros: This is a mission driven company
cons: Some executive staff members are not professional
